What started as a simple issue soon spiraled into a game of smoke and mirrors so confusing and corrupt, the Devil himself would want to take notes. \\\<br/\\\>

X[S] The simple assault charge led to heinous accusations of treason, conspiracy, and the attempted murder of a royal family member---an act that took place while His Grace was busy defending the lives of Italian citizens in active battle. \\\<br/\\\>\\\<br/\\\>Despite this lack of evidence and without any respect for his station or service, Marcellio remained incarcerated for weeks after the initial arrest. And then, the twisted reach of unnamed, nefarious enemies struck again. \\\<br/\\\>

X[S] While in prison, His Grace di Giordio suffered a grievous assault that nearly took his life. Initial requests that he be moved to house arrest, something many would consider the most ethical, humane thing to do, were met by His Majesty's disdain.\\\<br/\\\>\\\<br/\\\>Only after making the impulsive, rash and frankly illegal decision to declare the victim of the alleged crime responsible for the suspect's actions did His Majesty permit the wounded war hero to recover from his injuries in the home he shared with his wife, but not after he demanded his own pound of flesh to the tune of fifty thousand florins bail. \\\<br/\\\>

X[S] Even more time passed as the investigation stalled due to the action, or rather inaction, of those highest within the ranks of the judicial system. But once the wheels of justice began to turn, there was no stopping the debacle that would soon follow. \\\<br/\\\>\\\<br/\\\>Facing off against an untried and untested prosecuting attorney, Chief Justice Emeraude di Farnese built a case so watertight, it seemed like Marcellio's fate would finally turn toward the light at the end of this smoke-filled hall of mirrors. \\\<br/\\\>\\\<br/\\\>Alas, that is not what happened. \\\<br/\\\>

X[S] On Sunday, October 3rd, 1603, in front of an audience filled with support for the war hero who had become a household name, the jury delivered their verdict. \\\<br/\\\>\\\<br/\\\>Duke Marcellio di Giordio was declared not guilty by a jury of Peers, and the Judge himself accepted this verdict as true and without prejudice. \\\<br/\\\>\\\<br/\\\>Evidently, His Majesty has little regard for the opinion of his Peers, though. \\\<br/\\\>

X[S] In an unprecedented act that breaks with tradition, morality, and ethics, His Majesty denied the findings of his Peerage and declared Marcellio guilty despite an appalling lack of evidence to prove his guilt. But our King was not finished there. \\\<br/\\\>\\\<br/\\\>He took his power one step further and demanded the victim of the alleged crimes be placed on immediate house arrest to face a repeat prosecution of the same crimes already heard by the court. \\\<br/\\\>\\\<br/\\\>And he took yet another step and demanded an investigation against the accused's wife be instigated to determine her complicity in the crimes Marcellio was deemed not guilty for by a jury of fourteen people the King chose to ignore. \\\<br/\\\>\\\<br/\\\>

X[S] His Majesty was not through with his reign of terror, though.\\\<br/\\\>\\\<br/\\\>On the morning of December 4th, when it was learned that Marcellio had disappeared among the riots that broke out, His Majesty demanded entrance to the Italian consulate---an act that flies in the face of all international laws established to protect the innocent from tyrannical rulers.\\\<br/\\\>\\\<br/\\\>When his request was rightly denied, he took it upon himself to violently assault the ambassador of the consulate trying to protect the people within it's sanctuary.\\\<br/\\\>\\\<br/\\\>As if that weren't enough, he immediately jailed a City Guardsman who came to the ambassador's defense, not with legally appropriate oversight from the City or Royal Guard, but with the personal protective detail of the Pope. \\\<br/\\\>\\\<br/\\\>When his actions were called out for their heinous disregard of proper law and order, his answer was to fire not only the Chief Justice, but also the Captain of the City and Royal Guard.\\\<br/\\\> \\\<br/\\\>\\\<br/\\\>

X[S] As a result of all these actions, it is clear that His Majesty has no respect for true justice.\\\<br/\\\>\\\<br/\\\>If he had any respect for justice, he would not have rebuked his Peerage's declaration of NOT GUILTY.\\\<br/\\\>\\\<br/\\\>If he had any respect for justice, he would not have charged the Archduke with the same crimes he had already declared another man guilty for.\\\<br/\\\>\\\<br/\\\>If he had any respect for justice, he would not have demanded an investigation be brought against the pregnant wife of a man declared NOT GUILTY by the courts. \\\<br/\\\>\\\<br/\\\>If he had any respect for justice, he would not have assaulted an ambassador of his own country's diplomatic consulate for protecting the rights of her people.\\\<br/\\\>\\\<br/\\\>If he had any respect for justice, he would not have arrested a City Guardsman for attempting to save a citizen from bodily injury. \\\<br/\\\>\\\<br/\\\>If he had any respect for justice, he would not have fired his Chief Justice for offering sound legal advice as is part of her job.\\\<br/\\\>\\\<br/\\\>If he had any respect for justice, he would not have fired his Captain of the Guards for demanding due process and proper procedure. \\\<br/\\\>\\\<br/\\\>This is not justice. This is a perversion of justice so terrifying, there are no words to adequately describe it. \\\<br/\\\>\\\<br/\\\>
